What is RecycLens?

RecycLens is a solution that simplifies and enhances everyday waste segregation. Using artificial intelligence, the app analyzes a photo of waste taken by the user and indicates the correct bin for disposal.
About Us
Information
Recycling - Quick and Easy
Remember, every small step toward conscious recycling is a significant contribution to protecting the environment and the future of our planet!
Have questions, suggestions, or encountered issues with the app? Contact us:
bednarowski.wojciech@gmail.com
tomeekwilk@icloud.com
How does the app work?

1. Take a photo of the item you want to dispose of.\n2. Using Roboflow and the MobileNet V2 Classification model, the artificial intelligence in RecycLens will recognize the waste and indicate the appropriate bin.\n3. You will receive a brief explanation of what can be disposed of in that bin and what to avoid to make recycling as effective as possible.
Why use RecycLens?

• Time-saving: Quick image analysis lets you know immediately where each waste item belongs.

• Environmental support: Helps maintain order and reduces landfill waste.

• Environmental education: Learn what to throw into each bin and how to segregate waste effectively.

• Accuracy: Our MobileNet V2 Classification model achieves over 96% accuracy in determining the correct bin for waste disposal.
What is waste segregation?

Waste segregation is the process of dividing waste into categories such as glass, paper, plastic, metal, and bio-waste. This enables reuse, contributing to environmental protection and reducing landfill waste.
Why is segregation important?

Segregation is important because it helps protect the environment and conserve natural resources. By segregating waste, recyclable materials can be separated from those requiring specialized disposal. This reduces the amount of waste sent to landfills, helping to limit soil, water, and air pollution.
What should go into the blue bin (paper)?

This bin should contain paper waste such as newspapers, cardboard, notebooks, sheets, and paper bags. Avoid throwing in greasy or dirty paper remnants, like food-stained paper towels. Make sure to remove staples and plastic components.
What should go into the yellow bin (plastic)?

This bin should contain all plastic packaging, such as bottles, yogurt cups, food containers, and plastic wraps. Ensure they are clean and empty before disposing of them. This bin is also for metal packaging like cans and aluminum lids.
What should go into the green bin (glass)?

This bin should contain glass waste like bottles, jars, perfume bottles, and glass containers. Do not throw in broken glass, ceramics, mirrors, or tempered glass, as they require separate disposal in mixed waste bins. Ensure containers are emptied before disposal.
What should go into the black bin (mixed)?

This bin should contain non-recyclable waste such as meat scraps, cooking oil, receipts, cigarette butts, broken glassware, and porcelain, as well as used paper towels and tissues. Try to avoid disposing of recyclable waste here.
What should go into the brown bin (bio-waste)?

This bin should contain biodegradable waste like vegetables, fruits, eggshells, coffee and tea grounds, flowers, potted plants, and food scraps. Avoid disposing of meat, dairy, fats, or wooden or synthetic materials. Bio-waste is suitable for composting, supporting natural soil processes.
What should go into the red bin (electronics)?

This bin should contain small electronic devices like batteries, chargers, phones, remote controls, headphones, and small household appliances. Do not dispose of large appliances here; they must be recycled at specialized facilities. Remember, improper disposal of electronics can harm the environment.
